trainingNotes.note: Warm up and do some easy jogging, then speed up to your green zone speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Get your gear ready for race day: the same shoes and clothes, all the good gear you've been training in. Nothing new. Enjoy! GOOD LUCK!

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Intervals in the Fartlek yellow zone.
trainingNotes.note: These yellow zones are run at your 5K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Run fast in each yellow zone, but don't stop to recover in the green. Keep running even if you need to slow down to a jog.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Controlled pace intervals in the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.note: Run each yellow zone at your race pace of between 8 and 12 km.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Stay in the zones. Run hard in each yellow zone and use the green zones for recovery. This workout will be tough, so do one set at a time.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Long race with a fast finish.
trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Try not to start in the yellow zone with too fast a pace. Ending the workout with the minimum effort for each zone should be your main goal.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and enjoy.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Keep a steady pace. Don't try to turn it into a hard workout - race day is just around the corner. You've already done all the work you need to do.

trainingNotes.note: Most of this race should be slow and easy in the blue and green zones. Speed up to half marathon race pace by the end of the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Training in the yellow zone improves your ability to sustain greater efforts for longer.

trainingNotes.note: Test your half marathon race pace goal in the long yellow zone today.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't shorten your cool-down. After a big effort in the yellow zone, you need to get rid of lactic acid. If you're tired, walk to recover.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and enjoy this longer slow run. Save your speed for the yellow zone of later workouts.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Long runs serve two distinct purposes: maximizing your ability to burn carbohydrates and fat and developing resistance to fatigue.

trainingNotes.note: Today is an easy and enjoyable run. Tomorrow you have a long training session ahead of you.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't put pressure on yourself today; don't worry. Rest up for tomorrow's long workout.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: The speed in the yellow zone is repeated.
trainingNotes.note: Run each of these yellow zones at your 5K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Speed work is the key to faster race times, so quench your thirst for speed.

trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't make the mistake of trying to run a race before race day. Stay comfortably in the green zone today. You'll be training your body to perform optimally on race day.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Long race with a fast finish.
trainingNotes.note: Most of this race should be slow and easy in the blue and green zones. Speed up to half marathon race pace by the end of the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Hydration helps prevent cramps. Water is fine, but sports drinks can provide the necessary electrolytes with a hint of flavor. Experiment now so that on race day you know what works best for you.

trainingNotes.note: No extra points are given for making this workout tougher. Don't push yourself too hard. Your body needs time to recover and adapt.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While workouts serve to stimulate the body, rest time is necessary for the body to adapt. These easy workouts are used to get the blood circulating in order to speed up recovery.

trainingNotes.note: Test your half marathon race pace goal in the long yellow zone today.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't shorten your cool-down. After a big effort in the yellow zone, you need to get rid of lactic acid. If you're tired, walk to recover.

trainingNotes.note: Listen to your body. Don't push the pace too hard for the blue and green zones. As you progress through the plan, you may have some days where you need to slow down.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: It's normal to feel tired a day or two after a long workout. Your body needs time to recover. Eat healthy and stay hydrated to help your body recover and adapt.

trainingNotes.note: Make time the goal, not speed or distance. Relax and find a comfortable pace in the green zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Your goal is time. Relax and go slow.

trainingNotes.note: Don't put pressure on yourself today; don't worry. Rest up for tomorrow's long workout.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Are you struggling with fatigue? Slow down and focus on maintaining good running posture.

trainingNotes.note: Your yellow zone pace should be slightly faster than your half marathon speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Speeding up will reduce your ability to sustain effort. Knowing your personal pace is what separates novice runners from experienced ones.

trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: As you gain confidence, sprint with a little more speed at the end of the red zone.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Long race with a fast finish.
trainingNotes.note: Most of this race should be slow and easy in the blue and green zones. Speed up to half marathon race pace by the end of the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Efforts in the yellow zone are above your lactic acid threshold. This is the point at which your body's ability to maintain speed declines rapidly. Start with an effort just above the green zone, at the bottom of the yellow zone. Only speed up as you gain confidence and can finish the interval.

trainingNotes.note: Listen to your body. Don't push the pace too hard for the blue and green zones. As you progress through the plan, you may have some days where you need to slow down.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: On race day, don't let adrenaline get the best of you. Remember your pace and stick to it. If you go too fast in the first few miles, you could lose a lot of speed near the end and not hit your personal best.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: The speed in the yellow zone is repeated.
trainingNotes.note: Itâ€™s time for speed. Run each of these yellow zones at your 5K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Speed work is the key to faster race times, so quench your thirst for speed.

trainingNotes.note: Make time the goal, not speed or distance. Relax and find a comfortable pace in the green zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: It's normal to feel tired a day or two after a long workout. Your body needs time to recover. Eat healthy and stay hydrated to help your body recover and adapt.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and run thinking about time and not distance.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Continuous long runs in the green zone will increase your ability to burn fat, store more glycogen and challenge your body and mind to keep running even when you are fatigued.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and stay within the zones. Try to make this workout comfortable for you. Finish feeling good, not tired.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't put pressure on yourself today; don't worry. Rest up for tomorrow's long workout.

trainingNotes.note: Run these long yellow zones at race pace between 12km and half marathon.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't shorten your cool-down. After a big effort in the yellow zone, you need to get rid of lactic acid. If you're tired, walk to recover.

trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: As you gain confidence, sprint with a little more speed at the end of the red zone.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Long race with a fast finish.
trainingNotes.note: Most of this race should be slow and easy in the blue and green zones. Speed up to half marathon race pace by the end of the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: When you run, visualize race day. Resist the urge to quit. Sometimes all you need to do is slow down a bit.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and stay within the zones. Try to make this workout comfortable for you. Finish feeling good, not tired.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: After yesterday's easy run, take care of your quads and calves with a slow, gentle stretch.

trainingNotes.note: Each series in the yellow zone consists of running at your 10K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Make these workouts into a game: try to reach the appropriate zones as quickly as possible. Don't slow down halfway through a zone, or go over the zones.

trainingNotes.note: This workout improves your endurance. The goal is time; speed doesn't matter. It's okay to run slower than your expected marathon speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Use this run to clear your mind and relax your body. Breathe, let go and daydream.

trainingNotes.note: Your goal is time. Relax and go slow.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Long runs can be tough. Discomfort and fatigue are normal. However, if you think you're starting to feel an injury, stop running before it gets worse.

trainingNotes.note: Listen to your body. Don't push the pace too hard for the blue and green zones. As you progress through the plan, you may have some days where you need to slow down.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: We'll take it easy today. We won't do anything too hard.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: The speed in the yellow zone is repeated.
trainingNotes.note: Itâ€™s time for speed. Run each of these yellow zones at your 5K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: How fast can you run without going outside the yellow zone? Find out today.

trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: When you run, visualize race day. Resist the urge to quit. Sometimes all you need to do is slow down a bit.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Long race with a fast finish.
trainingNotes.note: Most of this race should be slow and easy in the blue and green zones. Speed up to half marathon race pace by the end of the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Hydration helps prevent cramps. Water is fine, but sports drinks can provide the necessary electrolytes with a hint of flavor. Experiment now so that on race day you know what works best for you.

trainingNotes.note: Warm up and do some easy jogging, then speed up to your green zone speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Make time the goal, not speed or distance. Relax and find a comfortable pace in the green zone.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Controlled pace intervals in the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.note: Run each yellow zone at your race pace of between 8 and 12 km.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: For more information on Cruise Interval training, visit www.McMillanRunning.com.

trainingNotes.note: This workout improves your endurance. The goal is time; speed doesn't matter. It's okay to run slower than your expected marathon speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Satisfy your desire for speed by increasing your stride length and unleashing the power of your legs.

trainingNotes.note: Don't go for speed on long runs. Go slow and make time your goal without rushing to get home early.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While heart rate zones will be customized to your profile, pace zones are specifically related to your running goal. To complete a half marathon in 1 hour and 10 minutes, adjust your zones from Settings so that the pace at the top of the red zone is 02:14:00 min/km (03:35:00 min/mile) and the pace at the top of the green zone is 03:25:00 min/km (05:30:00 min/mile).

trainingNotes.note: Make time your goal, relax and enjoy this long run. Use the minimum effort necessary to stay in the green zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Do you have trouble feeling motivated some days? Focus on your warm-up, and when you're done, you'll likely be excited to run.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Intervals in the Fartlek yellow zone.
trainingNotes.note: These yellow zones are run at your 5K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Pick up the pace. When you are in the yellow zone, run at the top of the zone, just below the red zone.

trainingNotes.note: Test your half marathon race pace goal in the long yellow zone today.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't shorten your cool-down. After a big effort in the yellow zone, you need to get rid of lactic acid. If you're tired, walk to recover.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and enjoy this longer slow run. Save your speed for the yellow zone of later workouts.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Find a balance with your workouts by sleeping well, eating well and drinking plenty of water. Remember that your body needs a good combination of work, play, sleep and healthy eating to achieve the best results.

trainingNotes.note: A nice, relaxing run. Focus on your breathing and take smooth, easy steps.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Take it easy today, save the motivation for tomorrow.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Intervals in the Fartlek yellow zone.
trainingNotes.note: These yellow zones are run at your 10K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Run fast in each yellow zone, but don't stop to recover in the green. Keep running even if you need to slow down to a jog.

trainingNotes.note: Each series in the yellow zone consists of running at your 10K race pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: These longer yellow zone intervals will be difficult to maintain. Focus on completing each yellow zone without slowing down.

trainingNotes.note: Most of this race should be slow and easy in the blue and green zones. Speed up to half marathon race pace by the end of the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Speeding up will reduce your ability to sustain effort. Knowing your personal pace is what separates novice runners from experienced ones.

trainingNotes.note: Make time the goal, not speed or distance. Relax and find a comfortable pace in the green zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Reserve today, because you already know what awaits you tomorrow.

trainingNotes.noteSummary: Intervals in the Fartlek yellow zone.
trainingNotes.note: Keep your speed under control in the yellow zone. You must make a running effort of between 5 and 10 km in each two-minute yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Run fast in each yellow zone, but don't stop to recover in the green. Keep running even if you need to slow down to a jog.

trainingNotes.note: Run these long yellow zones at race pace between 12km and half marathon.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: For more information on different training paces, visit: www.McMillanRunning.com

trainingNotes.note: Relax and run thinking about time and not distance.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While heart rate zones will be customized to your profile, pace zones are specifically related to your running goal. To complete a half marathon in 1 hour and 10 minutes, adjust your zones from Settings so that the pace at the top of the red zone is 02:14:00 min/km (03:35:00 min/mile) and the pace at the top of the green zone is 03:25:00 min/km (05:30:00 min/mile).

trainingNotes.note: Go out the door and run.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While workouts serve to stimulate the body, rest time is necessary for the body to adapt. These easy workouts are used to get the blood circulating in order to speed up recovery.

trainingNotes.note: The length of these longer yellow zones can be difficult to maintain. Move at a pace around the bottom of your yellow zone to ensure you can finish.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: If you are unable to maintain a pace in the yellow zone for this workout, adjust the top of the green zone to go slightly slower.

trainingNotes.note: These short bursts of speed are designed to improve your running posture. Take as much time as you need to recover in the blue zone to get the most out of your workout.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Satisfy your desire for speed by increasing your stride length and unleashing the power of your legs.

trainingNotes.note: Don't rush to finish long runs early. Your goal is time. Go slow and take on this workout with confidence.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Make time your goal, relax and enjoy this long run. Use the minimum effort necessary to stay in the green zone.

trainingNotes.note: Speed is not important for this workout. Keep your effort comfortably within the zones.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Make time your goal, relax and enjoy this long run. Use the minimum effort necessary to stay in the green zone.

trainingNotes.note: It is a common mistake to run these longer yellow zones too fast. Stay around the bottom of your yellow zone. Your goal is to improve your lactic acid threshold with a sustained â€œhard but comfortableâ€ effort.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: If you are unable to maintain a pace in the yellow zone for this workout, adjust the top of the green zone to go slightly slower.

trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: These series will go a long way in increasing your ability to run with more power over longer distances. Push yourself to the limit and you will see the results on race day.

trainingNotes.note: Go slow. Make time your goal and finish your workout feeling good.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While heart rate zones will be customized to your profile, pace zones are specifically related to your running goal. To complete a half marathon in 1 hour and 10 minutes, adjust your zones from Settings so that the pace at the top of the red zone is 02:14:00 min/km (03:35:00 min/mile) and the pace at the top of the green zone is 03:25:00 min/km (05:30:00 min/mile).

trainingNotes.note: Today, put in minimal effort to reach each area. Don't worry about speed, just put in the time.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Find a balance with your workouts by sleeping well, eating well and drinking plenty of water. Remember that your body needs a good combination of work, play, sleep and healthy eating to achieve the best results.

trainingNotes.note: The length of these longer yellow zones can be difficult to maintain. Move at a pace around the bottom of your yellow zone to ensure you can finish.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: It is a common mistake to run these longer yellow zones too fast. Stay around the bottom of your yellow zone. Your goal is to improve your lactic acid threshold with a sustained â€œhard but comfortableâ€ effort.

trainingNotes.note: Pick up the pace. Pick up speed when you enter the red zone. Slow down to a jog when you enter the blue zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: The time you spend in zones is a better way to measure training stress than distance. Two different runners can run different distances in a 50-minute green zone, but the training stress on their bodies will be the same. Forcing the two runners to run exactly 8 km could result in too much stress on one and not enough stress on the other.

trainingNotes.note: Pick up the pace. Your pace for sets in the yellow zone is equivalent to your half marathon race pace or slightly faster.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't shorten your cool-down. After a big effort in the yellow zone, you need to get rid of lactic acid. If you're tired, walk to recover.

trainingNotes.note: A nice, relaxing run. Focus on your breathing and take smooth, easy steps.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Rest is important. Without rest, your workouts will be just stress, with no benefits.

trainingNotes.note: The length of these longer yellow zones can be difficult to maintain. Move at a pace around the bottom of your yellow zone to ensure you can finish.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: It is a common mistake to run these longer yellow zones too fast. Stay around the bottom of your yellow zone. Your goal is to improve your lactic acid threshold with a sustained â€œhard but comfortableâ€ effort.

trainingNotes.note: Start with a slow run in the blue zone. Gradually accelerate within the green zone. Increase speed in the yellow zone. Sprint to finish in the short red zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: These workouts help you improve your lactic acid threshold, which will help your body adapt to more intense efforts for longer periods of time.

trainingNotes.note: Don't go for speed on long runs. Go slow and make time your goal without rushing to get home early.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Running in the blue zone is a very easy effort. Don't start off too fast, save your motivation for the next workout.

trainingNotes.note: Make time your goal. The blue zone represents a slow, gentle effort, while the green zone represents a comfortable effort. You should breathe in such a way that you are able to say entire sentences without having to stop for air.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While intervals and long runs are key workouts, daily runs like this one serve to build a foundation. Do your best to make time for this workout.

trainingNotes.note: Run each yellow zone maintaining your pace. This is equivalent to your race effort for the half marathon.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: As you maintain your effort, your breathing should become more pronounced, but you should not be out of breath. The challenge of this workout should be the duration, not the pace.

trainingNotes.note: Build up speed each time you reach the red zone until you are sprinting, then slow down to a slow recovery jog in the blue zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: For more information on step rate, visit www.McMillanRunning.com.

trainingNotes.note: Long, slow runs are important for achieving fast race times. To endure and recover from the hardest efforts, a strong aerobic system is necessary.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: This workout improves your endurance. The goal is time; speed doesn't matter. It's okay to run slower than your expected marathon speed.

trainingNotes.note: Today, feel comfortable in the green zone. Tomorrow you will go further.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Adjust the zones to help you control your efforts. The blue zone is slow and easy, the green zone is a medium effort, below the lactic acid threshold.

trainingNotes.note: Run in the yellow zone at a steady pace. This should be somewhere between your 30K race pace and your half marathon pace.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: For more information on different training paces, visit: www.McMillanRunning.com

trainingNotes.note: Finish this race with your 10K race effort in the yellow zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Don't shorten your cool-down. After a big effort in the yellow zone, you need to get rid of lactic acid. If you're tired, walk to recover.

trainingNotes.note: Running in the blue zone is a very easy effort. Don't start off too fast, save your motivation for the next workout.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Adjust the zones to help you control your efforts. The blue zone is slow and easy, the green zone is a medium effort, below the lactic acid threshold.

trainingNotes.note: Warm up and do some easy jogging, then speed up to your green zone speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Adjust the zones to help you control your efforts. The blue zone is slow and easy, the green zone is a medium effort, below the lactic acid threshold.

trainingNotes.note: Make these workouts fun: try to get to the zones as quickly as possible. Don't slow down halfway through the zone, and you shouldn't go over the zones either.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Heart rate helps you gauge your effort. As your fitness improves, you'll find that you can run faster for the same effort.

trainingNotes.note: We'll take it easy today. We won't do anything too hard.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Adjust the zones to help you control your efforts. The blue zone is slow and easy, the green zone is a medium effort, below the lactic acid threshold.

trainingNotes.note: Warm up and do some easy jogging, then speed up to your green zone speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While heart rate zones will be customized to your profile, pace zones are specifically related to your running goal. To complete a half marathon in 1 hour and 10 minutes, adjust your zones from Settings so that the pace at the top of the red zone is 02:14:00 min/km (03:35:00 min/mile) and the pace at the top of the green zone is 03:25:00 min/km (05:30:00 min/mile).

trainingNotes.note: No extra points are given for making this workout tougher. Don't push yourself too hard. Your body needs time to recover and adapt.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Create a couple of playlists tailored to these familiar green zone races.

trainingNotes.note: Test your half marathon race pace goal in the long yellow zone today.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: The time you spend in zones is a better way to measure training stress than distance. Two different runners can run different distances in a 40-minute green zone, but the training stress on their bodies will be the same. Forcing the two runners to run exactly 8 km could result in too much stress on one and not enough stress on the other.

trainingNotes.note: Warm up and do some easy jogging, then speed up to your green zone speed.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Rest is important. Without rest, your workouts will be just stress, with no benefits.

trainingNotes.note: Relax and enjoy the slow pace in the blue zones. This gentle effort helps improve the aerobic system while keeping the training stress at a minimum.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: While heart rate zones will be customized to your profile, pace zones are specifically related to your running goal. To complete a half marathon in 1 hour and 10 minutes, adjust your zones from Settings so that the pace at the top of the red zone is 02:14:00 min/km (03:35:00 min/mile) and the pace at the top of the green zone is 03:25:00 min/km (05:30:00 min/mile).

trainingNotes.note: Make time the goal, not speed or distance. Relax and find a comfortable pace in the green zone.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: Instead of long, powerful steps, focus on shorter, quicker steps. Your foot should touch the ground just below your body, not too far in front of you.

trainingNotes.note: Long yellow zones are slower than short yellow zones. The pace should be a race effort that you could maintain if you were motivated for about an hour, which is typically the race pace for a half marathon.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: It is a common mistake to run these longer yellow zones too fast. Stay around the bottom of your yellow zone. Your goal is to improve your lactic acid threshold with a sustained â€œhard but comfortableâ€ effort.

trainingNotes.note: Each time you enter the red zone, increase your speed until you reach your maximum speed at the end of the zone. Slow down again with an easy recovery jog for each blue zone. Strive to maintain good running form throughout the race.
trainingNotes.secondaryNote: The steps should be very short bursts of speed. They help train the neuromuscular system to be faster. Go ahead and see how fast you can run in each red zone. Once you reach top speed, slow down again for a gentle recovery in the blue zone.
